title: Compton Dundon and Combe Hill Wood Walking Route

images.title: Patrick Mackie / Compton Street, Compton Dundon
images.caption: Compton Street, Compton Dundon

images.title: Neville Goodman / Woodland walks
images.caption: Woodland walks. Combe Hill is private land, but the landlord, together with the Forestry Commission, manage a delightful wood, with information boards and waymarked paths.

images.title: Brian Roberts / View towards Compton Dundon
images.caption: View towards Compton Dundon

images.title: Brian Roberts / Carved Seat above Compton Dundon
images.caption: Carved Seat above Compton Dundon

images.title: Shaun Ferguson / From Meadway Hall looking up to Dundon Hill
images.caption: From Meadway Hall looking up to Dundon Hill. The hill fort at the top dates to 700 BC. An excavation in 1916 found pottery and flints here, but the fort has been damaged by quarrying.

images.title: Looking towards Dundon Beacon from Collard Hill. by Pam Goodey, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking towards Dundon Beacon from Collard Hill.

images.title: Shaun Ferguson / Looking up to the Admiral Hood memorial
images.caption: From Compton Street looking up to the Admiral Hood memorial on Windmill Hill

images.title: Nick Chipchase / The Hood Monument in Autumn
images.caption: The Hood Monument in Autumn. The monument celebrates Admiral Sir Samuel Hood. It has been designated by English Heritage as a Grade II* listed building. It was completed in 1831 to a design by Henry Goodridge.

description: This circular walk explores the area around the Somerset village of Compton Dundon. On the way you'll visit The Hood Monument and Combe Hill Woods before a climb to Dundon Beacon where you can enjoy some fine views over the area. The walk starts in the village and heads north to The Hood Monument. The hilltop monument is something of a local landmark and sits atop windmill hill. There's some fine views to Glastonbury Tor from this historic spot. From here you head south east to Combe Hill Wood. Here you can enjoy miles of peaceful woodland trail through Great Breach Wood and Copley Wood. From the high points in the woods there are some lovely views over the surrounding countryside. The route then heads west toward Dundon where you can climb to the Iron Age Hillfort at Dundon Beacon. The area is a nature reserve with some lovely flora and fauna to look out for.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: Back in the village you can enjoy some post exercise rest and refreshment at The Castlebrook Inn. There pub has a nice garden area and there is also a large conservatory restaurant towards the rear. They serve good quality food and can be found at postcode TA11 6PR for your sat navs.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The woodland trails on the route are ideal for dog walking. The Castlebrook Inn mentioned above is also dog friendly.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The woods are located just to the north of the noteworthy town of Somerton. You can enjoy some wonderful historic buildings, riverside walks along the River Cary and visit one of the local highlights at the National Trust's Lytes Cary manor. To the north lies Street where you can enjoy walks along the Polden Way through the Polden Hills.
